The 'smooth toadfish' or 'smooth toado' (Tetractenos glaber,
formerly classified as Tetrodon
glaber [http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=282944 World
Register of Marine Species - Tetractenos glaber (FrÃ©minville, 1813)], accessed
27 January 2010. G.S. Hardy, "Revision of Australian
species of Torquigener Whitley (Tetraodontiformes: Tetraodontidae), and two new
generic names for Australian puffer fishes," Journal of the Royal Society of New
Zealand, Volume 13, No. 1/2, 1983, pp. 1â48. [http://books.google.com.au/books?-
id=nLA4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q=&f=false] or Torquigener
glaber Sarah L. Green, "Ultrastructure and innervation of the swimbladder of
Tetractenos glaber (Tetraodontidae)," Cell and Tissue Research, Volume 237, No.
2, August, 1984, pp. 277-284.
[http://www.springerlink.com/content/t78674583v773149/] ) is a species of
fish in the Tetraodontidae family of order Tetraodontiformes, found along
Australia's eastern and southeast coast, from northern Queensland to South
Australia and Tasmania. [http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/abrs/online-
resources/fauna/afd/taxa/Tetractenos_glaber Australian Faunal Directory:
Tetractenos glaber.] It is one of the most abundant fishes in the muddy
areas of Port Philip Bay. Melbourne's Wildlife (Museum Victoria, 2006),
324.

The diet of the smooth toadfish includes molluscs and small crabs, and it often
follows the tide into estuaries in search of food. [http://www.mesa.edu.au/ask/display.asp?id=1 Marine Education
Society of Australasia web site], accessed 27 January 2010. The fish has a
maximum length of 15 cm. [http://www.fishbase.org/summary/speciessummary.php?id=52455
Fishbase - Tetractenos glaber], accessed 27 January 2010
([http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Tetractenos+glaber%22+fishbase find
mirrors]). As with other fish of this family, the flesh is poisonous, due to tetrodotoxin, and eating the fish can have fatal consequen-
ces. [http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/177_11_021202/isb10423_fm.html
Puffer fish poisoning: a potentially life-threatening condition], accessed 8
March 2010.

Because it is a common estuarine fish, it has been used in studies of heavy
metal contamination in coastal waters. Ralph Alquezar, Scott J. Markich, and
David J. Booth, "Metal accumulation in the smooth toadfish, Tetractenos glaber,
in estuaries around Sydney, Australia," Environmental Pollution, Volume 142, No.
1, July 2006, pp. 123-131, ISSN 0269-7491, . [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6VB5-4J9X1PV-
1/2/1a0760c63cdd9bc03452103119907806]

Along with related toadfish species, the smooth toadfish is known in Australia
as a "toadie."
